text: rush hour in Bogota Colombia sleek red
buses glide past bumper-to-bumper
traffic the buses are part of a novel
public transportation system called bus
rapid transit or BRT over the last
decade developing cities around the
world have been adapting bus systems
like Bogota for three reasons
they cut down traffic they're cheaper
than building Subway's and they improve
the environment by using TransMilenio
because it's much quicker to arrive at
the University or work or whatever place
because traffic jams in Bogota are
impossible to arrive at the University
on the TransMilenio it takes me
approximately half an hour but by car it
takes me about an hour and a half or two
hours so it's much quicker Bogota system
called TransMilenio opened in 2001 and
was one of the first in the world
it operates like an above ground subway
with isolated lanes like tracks and
buses like trams
jános how off request m8n transporte
público I didn't use public
transportation for precisely that reason
that it was very disorganized I used my
own vehicle now I use it more frequently
because it takes less time
environmental experts say curbing the
rise of greenhouse gas emissions from
the developing world is crucial in the
fight to combat global warming in Bogota
there are now seven thousand fewer buses
on the roads and the amount of bus fuel
used and the greenhouse gas emissions
generated have dropped by nearly 50
percent with TransMilenio I can avoid
using my vehicle and spending money on
gasoline and I arrive much faster to my
destination the TransMilenio is the only
transit system in the world allowed to
generate and sell carbon credits to
countries that exceed their greenhouse
gas emission limits
Bogota system is now more advanced than
many transit systems in more developed
countries
